Award.AwardTitle: Formation and biological activity of functional protein aggregates

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Formation and biological activity of functional protein aggregates

The interior of cells contains high concentrations of protein. Cells have complex systems to prevent these proteins from aggregating. However, recent evidence has shown that the aggregation of specific proteins is used to regulate various important cellular functions. In this research project, the investigators will use a combination of genetic, biochemical and computer modeling techniques to develop improved methods to predict this particular protein aggregation, and to examine how such aggregates are used to regulate cellular functions. This project will offer diverse interdisciplinary training to junior scientists. A portion of the research will be conducted in the context of a novel laboratory course, which is designed to be a hybrid of independent research and traditional laboratory classes. This course will allow students to generate new, publishable research, but in a sufficiently structured setting to allow for training of a large number of students. Additionally, the PI will continue to expand his "Biochemistry is Elementary" outreach program. This program introduces elementary school students to the scientific process and to basic concepts in biochemistry using exciting, hands-on activities.

Despite the growing realization of the importance of prions and prion-like aggregation in normal cellular physiology, the exact basis for and regulation of these aggregation events are poorly understood. In this project, the investigators will utilize a combination of genetic, biochemical and computer modeling techniques to develop improved methods to predict prion-like aggregation and to examine how prion-like aggregation of RNA binding proteins affects the formation of cytoplasmic RNA-protein granules. The first goal is to develop better tools to predict prion aggregation and to predict how protein modifications affect prion activity. These studies will generate new resources to facilitate searches for new prion-like elements, and will provide key insight into the regulation of prion-like aggregation. The second goal of the project is to examine the role of prion-like domains in the formation of cytoplasmic RNA-proteins granules. These studies will provide a framework for studying functional protein aggregation, while offering insight into the role of prion-like aggregation in post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prions are infectious proteins that generally result from the conversion of proteins from their soluble form into insoluble amyloid aggregates. Interestingly, many proteins contain prion-like domains, which are protein segments that resemble yeast prion domains. In recent years, controlled assembly of prion-like domains has been shown to regulate a variety of biological processes. In particular, many RNA binding proteins contain prion-like domains, and assembly of these prion-like proteins is thought to regulate RNA localization, translation and turnover. Therefore, the primary research goals of this project were to develop improved methods to predict aggregation of prion and prion-like proteins, and to examine the aggregation of RNA binding proteins.

These experiment led to three major discoveries. First, to better understand the sequence requirements for prion and prion-like aggregation, we screened a variety of predicted prion-like proteins for their assembly activity. These experiments identified a number of new candidate prion-like proteins, and revealed insights into the features that cause some prion-like proteins to form stable amyloid aggregates. Second, these studies led to the identification of a novel regulator of stress granules. Stress granules are RNA-protein assemblies that form in the cytoplasm of cells in response to a variety of cellular stresses. One of the prion-like proteins from our prion screen was found to be recruited to stress granules via its prion-like domain, and to facilitate dissolution of stress granules during recovery from stress. Third, we developed a novel bioinformatics method to examine protein domains such as prion-like domains. One challenge in identifying prion-like proteins involved in cellular assemblies such as stress granules is that all existing prediction algorithms were optimized for yeast prions, which form amyloid-based aggregates; by contrast, prion-like domains in stress granules are thought to form non-amyloid assemblies. Both prion domains and the prion-like domains in stress granules are low-complexity domains, meaning that they are enriched in a subset of the amino acids; however, they show slightly different amino acid biases. Therefore, we developed a broader bioinformatics method to screen genomes for low complexity domains enriched in specific amino acids. Interestingly, we found that which amino acids are enriched in the low complexity domain significantly affects characteristics such as protein stability, expression efficiency, and localization.

In addition to these research discoveries, this grant supported two broader impact aims. First, the project provided extensive opportunities for undergraduate research. Many of the experiments were done by undergraduates, either working independently or in a group laboratory course. Second, the grant helped support an elementary school outreach project called “Biochemistry is Elementary.”  This project introduces 5th grade students to the scientific process and to basic concepts in biochemistry using exciting, hands-on activities.
